metadata.case_name: State of Madras v. Srimathi Champakam Dorairajan & State of Madras v. C.R. Srinivasan

facts.text: State of Madras maintains four Medical Colleges with 330 seats: 17 reserved for students from outside the State, 12 for discretionary allotment by the State, balance apportioned between four distinct groups of districts.

State of Madras maintains four Engineering Colleges with 395 seats: 21 reserved for students from outside the State, 12 for discretionary allotment by the State, balance apportioned between four distinct groups of districts.

For many years before the commencement of the Constitution, seats in Medical and Engineering Colleges apportioned between four groups of districts were filled according to Communal G.O.: for every 14 seats - Non-Brahmin Hindus 6, Backward Hindus 2, Brahmins 2, Harijans 2, Anglo-Indians and Indian Christians 1, Muslims 1.
Selection from applicants from a particular community from one of the groups of districts made on principles based on academic qualifications and marks obtained by candidates.
In Medical Colleges, not less than 20% of seats available for students of the State filled by women candidates separately for each region.

Proportion fixed in old Communal G.O. adhered to even after commencement of Constitution on January 26, 1950; G.O. No. 2208 dated June 16, 1950, substantially reproduces communal proportion for Medical Colleges.

Srimathi Champakam Dorairajan (Brahmin) made application to Madras High Court on June 7, 1950, under Art. 226 for writ restraining enforcement of Communal G.O. for Medical College admissions; had not actually applied for admission but feared denial due to community.
High Court allowed Champakam Dorairajan's application by judgment dated July 27, 1950.

C.R. Srinivasan applied for admission to Government Engineering College at Guindy; passed Intermediate Examination in March 1950 in first class, secured 369 marks out of 450 in optionals for academic test.
Srinivasan filed petition under Art. 226 praying for writ restraining enforcement of Communal G.O. for Engineering College admissions.
High Court allowed Srinivasan's application by same judgment dated July 27, 1950.
State of Madras filed appeals to Supreme Court: Case No. 270 of 1951 (Champakam) and Case No. 271 of 1951 (Srinivasan) under Art. 132.
State conceded that both applicants would have been admitted if selections made on merits alone.
Srinivasan secured more marks than many Non-Brahmin candidates who would be admitted under quota.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Communal G.O. laying down communal proportions for admission to Medical and Engineering Colleges violates fundamental rights under Article 15(1) and Article 29(2) of the Constitution.
Whether directive principles under Article 46 override fundamental rights under Articles 15(1) and 29(2).

petitioner_arguments.text: Provisions of Article 46 charge the State with promoting educational interests of weaker sections, including Scheduled Castes and Tribes; State entitled to maintain Communal G.O. fixing proportionate seats for communities; no infringement of fundamental rights; Article 46 overrides Article 29(2).

respondent_arguments.text: Communal G.O. infringes fundamental rights under Article 15(1) and Article 29(2) by denying admission on grounds only of caste, religion, race.

court_reasoning.text: Article 29(2) guarantees individual citizen right to admission into State-maintained educational institutions not to be denied on grounds only of religion, race, caste, language; applies even if candidate has requisite qualifications.
Directive principles in Part IV (including Article 46) unenforceable by courts and cannot override enforceable fundamental rights in Part III; fundamental rights sacrosanct.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Directive principles subsidiary to fundamental rights.

court_reasoning.text: Absence of provision in Article 29 similar to Article 16(4) for reservation of backward classes significant; no communal considerations intended for educational admissions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Omission of clause like Art. 16(4) deliberate.

court_reasoning.text: Denial of admission to Srinivasan despite higher marks than candidates from other communities solely on ground of being Brahmin violates Article 29(2).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Classification proceeds on basis of religion, race, caste.

court_reasoning.text: Petition maintainable despite Champakam not applying for admission, as State agreed to reserve seat if successful.

holdings.text: Communal G.O. violates Article 29(2) and Article 15(1) as it denies admission on grounds only of caste, religion, race.
Directive principles of State policy cannot override fundamental rights.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Communal G.O. held violative of Arts. 15(1) and 29(2); Arts. 46 etc. directive principles do not override Part III rights.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court rejects State's contentions completely; upholds High Court judgments allowing writ petitions restraining enforcement of Communal G.O. as violative of fundamental rights.
outcome.relief_granted: Writs restraining State from enforcing Communal G.O.

key_quotes.text: The directive principles of the State policy, which by article 37 are expressly made unenforceable by a Court, cannot override the provisions found in Part III.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes primacy of fundamental rights over directive principles.

key_quotes.text: The chapter of Fundamental Rights is sacrosanct and not liable to be abridged by any Legislative or Executive Act or order.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms inviolability of Part III rights.

key_quotes.text: Such denial of admission cannot but be regarded as made on ground only of his caste.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Directly applies Art. 29(2) to facts of denial based on community.
